arm_group.description: Receives thoracic spine manipulation in the direction of motion limitation.

brief_summary.textblock:
Hypothesis: There is no difference in directional specific manipulation of the thoracic
      spine for patients with neck pain.

      Patients seeking physical therapy for neck pain routinely have their thoracic spine
      manipulated.  This study seeks to determine if directional limitations in the spine can be
      specifically determined and treated to decrease neck pain.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Directional Specific Thoracic Spine Mobilization on Cervical Spine Pain

detailed_description.textblock:
Manipulation of the thoracic spine is the most commonly used manual therapy intervention by
      manual therapists.  It is not known whether we can accurately assess and treat directional
      limitations in the thoracic spine to improve neck pain.

      One way is to assess where the limitation is and treat it.  Another method is to distract
      the joint.  We want to know if matching the limitation to the manipulation method will give
      patients with neck pain better results.

      The patient lays on their back.  The therapist places a hand on the inferior vertebrae of
      the motion segment.  The patient relaxes and the therapist pushes in an anterior to
      posterior direction either moving the vertebrae into flexion or entension.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with Neck Pain; ages 18 - 60

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  red flags: leg weakness, night pain, history of cancer, upper motor neuron signs,
             infection, tumors, osteoporosis, fracture  (Boissonnault, 2011) (Cleland, 2004)
             history of whiplash within 6 weeks, cervical stenosis, CNS involvement, signs
             consistent with nerve root compression, previous surgery, pending legal action

intervention.description: a manual technique applied to the mid back to promote motion

clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Directional Specific Thoracic Spine Mobilization on Cervial Spine Pain.

oversight_info.authority: United States: Chatham University Institutional Review Board

primary_outcome.description: Objective, valid, reliable measure of function in patients with neck pain.  Completed as a survey.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Selection of 0 to 10 level of pain.

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
